author: Gunvor Hofmo
title: Bird
synopsis: Gunvor Hofmo's poetry collection Fuglen (The Bird) was published in 1990, towards the end of her prolific career. Known for her free verse style and themes of existential despair and isolation, Hofmo is considered one of Norway's most influential modernist poets. Fuglen explores the human condition through the metaphor of a bird, a symbol of freedom and transcendence

history.title: Poetry and Tragedy: The Love Story of Ruth Maier and Gunvor Hofmo

introduction.text: In the dark days of World War II, an unusual love blossomed on Norwegian soil. This is the story of Ruth Maier and Gunvor Hofmo - a tale of passion, poetry, and irreplaceable loss that forever changed Norwegian literature.

chapters.title: The Meeting of Two Souls
content: Autumn 1940. Norway is under German occupation. 19-year-old Gunvor Hofmo, a vivacious and sharp-tongued girl from Oslo, arrives as a volunteer at a farm near Lake Mjøsa. Here she meets Ruth Maier, a Jewish refugee from Vienna, whose beauty and intellect immediately captivate Gunvor.
Ruth, who fled Austria in 1939, quickly learned Norwegian and excelled in her studies. An instant, deep connection forms between the girls.

In her diary, Ruth will write: 'The days become brighter when you love someone. When Gunvor isn't here, something is missing in me. Only when she appears somewhere in my field of vision do I sigh with relief. There she is!'

chapters.title: Love in Wartime
content: Their relationship blossoms against a backdrop of occupation and oppression. The girls move from farm to farm, taking on any work they can find. For a time, they even run a flower shop together in Trondheim.
Back in Oslo, Ruth enrolls in the School of Arts and Crafts, posing for sculptors to finance her education. Throughout all this, Gunvor remains her anchor and support.

Their love is not without complications. Ruth confesses in her diary: 'I have hurt Gunvor and even hit her, but she understands, and her smile remains the same. It's a beautiful smile, always understanding or wanting to understand. It's because she's so good that I dare to show that I love her.'

chapters.title: The Day the World Collapsed
content: November 26, 1942. A cold, dark day in Oslo. 21-year-old Gunvor watches in horror as her beloved Ruth is forcibly made to board the ship D/S Donau. This moment will haunt Gunvor for the rest of her days, inspiring some of the most poignant poetry in Norwegian literature.

Three years later, upon learning of Ruth's fate in Auschwitz, Gunvor writes: 'I saw my friend, the only one, go to die. And since then the trees have mourned, and since then Death has drawn my body and soul and voice into the sea of despair.'

chapters.title: A Life Dedicated to Poetry and Pain
content: Ruth never returned. Gunvor's grief became all-consuming, distancing her from those around her who could not fathom the depth of her loss.

Poetry became her only outlet, vibrating with anger and black despair. Gunvor's works would make her one of Norway's greatest modernist poets, her verses becoming a testament to lost love and the inhumanity she had witnessed.
In her perhaps most famous poem 'Det er ingen hverdag mer' (There is No Everyday Anymore), Gunvor captured the horror of what had happened:

chapters.title: The Legacy of Love
content: Ruth Maier's life tragically ended in Auschwitz in 1942, she was only 22 years old. Her diaries, preserved by Gunvor, were later published, giving voice to her experiences as a Jewish refugee in Norway.

Gunvor Hofmo lived until 1995, producing twenty collections of poetry and receiving numerous awards. Despite periods of hospitalization and isolation, she never stopped writing. Her work was forever shaped by her love for Ruth and the trauma of her loss.
Together, Ruth and Gunvor's story stands as a powerful testament to love in the face of hatred, and the enduring power of words to bear witness to both the best and worst of humanity.

key_figures.name: Ruth Maier
key_figures.description: Jewish writer from Vienna who fled to Norway in 1939. Arrested on November 26, 1942, and deported to Auschwitz, where she perished. Lover of poet Gunvor Hofmo.

key_figures.name: Gunvor Hofmo
key_figures.description: Born in Oslo, considered one of Norway's greatest modernist poets. Author of twenty poetry collections, recipient of numerous awards. Spent several years in Gaustad psychiatric hospital and later lived in isolation until her death.

legacy.literature: Gunvor Hofmo's poetry became one of the most poignant voices in post-war Norwegian literature
legacy.memory: The publication of Ruth Maier's diaries in 2014 drew attention to the fate of Jewish refugees in Norway
legacy.lgbt_history: The story of Ruth and Gunvor became an important part of Norway's LGBT history from the wartime period
